I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed results-
based  loan  to  the  Perusahaan  Listrik  Negara  (State  Electricity  Corporation)  [PLN],  to  be 
guaranteed by the Republic of Indonesia, for the Sustainable and Reliable Energy Access 
Program—Western and Central Java.1 The report also describes the proposed administration of 
technical assistance (TA) to be provided by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund for Capacity Development in Emerging Technologies, and if the Board approves 
the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the 
administration of the TA. 
 
2.  The program covers five provinces in the western and central parts of Java island—
Banten, Central Java, Jakarta Special Capital Region, West Java, and Yogyakarta Special 
Region—collectively home to 41% of Indonesia’s 270 million people.2 The expected outcome is 
enhanced access to sustainable and reliable energy for the population in Western and Central 
Java. Three output results contribute to the outcome: (i) power grid rehabilitated, strengthened, 
and expanded; (ii) clean energy use promoted; and (iii) institutional capacity strengthened. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Strategic Context 
 
3.  Country context. Following the Asian financial crisis in 1998 and until 2019, Indonesia’s 
economy grew at an annual rate of 5% or more. The steady economic growth coupled with strong 
pro-poor policies helped lift income levels and, with a gross national per capita income of $4,050, 
Indonesia became an upper middle-income country in 2020.3 However, the severe economic 
disruption due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has caused the per capita gross 
national income to decline to $3,870, and Indonesia was reclassified as a lower middle-income 
country in 2021. Indonesia’s economy contracted by 2.1% in 2020, for the first time in 21 years. 
With the onset of COVID-19, about 30 million workers were adversely affected in 2020 by 
reduction in working hours, suspension of employment, and job losses. Workers’ wages fell by 
5.2%  year-over-year,  and  many  moved  back  to  agriculture,  a  reversal  in  the  structural 
transformation of the economy. An additional 2.8 million people have fallen below the poverty line, 
with poverty incidence increasing from 9.2% in 2019 to 10.2% in 2020, which reversed the 
trajectory of declining poverty since 2006. The National Medium-Term Development Plan 2020–
2024 (RPJMN),4 in conjunction with COVID-19 recovery strategies being formulated by the 
government, seeks to address these challenges in support of boosting the economy and reducing 
poverty. Sustainable infrastructure investments will be instrumental in supporting these objectives 
as they will help increase productive capacity, create employment, and lift economic growth rates, 
while strengthening Indonesia's resilience to withstand future climate risks. 
 
 
1  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided transaction TA. ADB. 2019. Technical Assistance to the Republic of 
Indonesia for Supporting Sustainable and Universal Electricity Access in Indonesia. Manila (TA 9559-INO) under a 
cluster TA program (ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Indonesia for Sustainable Infrastructure 
Assistance Program. Manila [C-TA 0013-INO] financed by the Government of Australia through the Department of 
Foreign Affairs and Trade and administered by ADB). 
2  Central Statistical Agency. Social and Population (accessed February 2021). 
3  In 2020, Indonesia was classified as an upper middle-income country, because its per capita gross national income 
had reached $4,050 in 2019. 
4  Government of Indonesia. 2020. National Medium-Term Development Plan 2020–2024 (RPJMN). Jakarta.

2 
4.  Sector context. Together with its subsidiaries, the PLN is responsible for sourcing and 
delivering electricity to end users.5 PLN’s Electricity Power Supply Business Plan (RUPTL), 2021–
2030,6 includes the following targets: near 100% electrification by 2022 and by 2030 increased 
generation  capacity  by  an  additional  40.6  gigawatts  (GW);  strengthened  transmission  and 
distribution systems for reliable and sustainable electricity supply; expanded smart grid projects; 
and expanded clean energy use through electric vehicle charging infrastructure and rooftop solar 
photovoltaic  systems.  As  part  of  the  Paris  Agreement,  Indonesia  committed  to  reducing 
greenhouse gas emissions and increasing the use of renewable energy. The investment needs 
for 2021–2030 for power generation, transmission, and distribution are $90.3 billion, of which 
$39.5 billion is to be financed by the private sector and $50.8 billion by the PLN. Cost recovery 
for grid development is difficult given tariff affordability and long payback periods. Sovereign 
funding support for electricity grid development lowers the PLN’s cost of capital and improves 
financial viability to fulfil its public service obligations.  
 
5.  The government is undertaking reforms in the sector, expanding private investment, 
improving gender equality, continuing subsidy reform, and strengthening the PLN’s governance 
and financial capacity.7 Within the PLN, reforms comprise five priority themes: (i) lean (efficiency 
and reliability, with digitalization of its major business processes including e-procurement), (ii) 
green (reducing dependence on fossil fuels and doubling the PLN’s current 7.8 GW of renewable 
energy capacity  by  2025),  (iii) innovation  (exploring  revenues  from  other  sources,  such  as 
electricity sales to the e-mobility sector), (iv) gender (enhancing career pathways for women), and 
(v)  customer  focus  (specifically  on  enhanced  digital  payment  mechanisms  and  improved 
communication).8 The energy sector will be fundamental to the government’s COVID-19 response 
and economic recovery program. Throughout the crisis, electricity supply has supported essential 
services and maintained productivity under work-from-home arrangements. 
 
6.  ADB support. The programmatic support by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
Indonesia in the energy sector includes (i) policy, institutional, and regulatory support through 
policy-based lending;9 (ii) comprehensive knowledge and capacity support, as well as special 
initiatives;10 (iii)  a  results-based  lending  (RBL)  program  for  electricity  grid  strengthening  in

3 
Sumatra (completed) and two electricity grid development RBL programs for Eastern Indonesia;11 
and (iv) nonsovereign and sovereign financing support for renewable energy projects.12 
 
B.  Program Rationale 
 
7.  Focus on Java. Java dominates Indonesia’s economy, contributing 59% of national gross 
domestic product (GDP) in 2020. It hosts most manufacturing hubs and 62% of the country’s 
micro and small enterprises (MSEs) (footnote 2). Java has achieved the national goal of universal 
electricity access; however, power quality issues, frequent interruptions, and electricity losses 
undermine its economic growth.13 Grid strengthening could have prevented the major blackouts 
experienced in Western and Central Java, including Jakarta, in 2019 and 2020.14 To achieve 
sustained and higher economic growth, Java will require 259 terawatt-hours of electricity by 2030, 
or 66.4% of the country’s total projected demand (footnote 4). Meeting this demand requires the 
strengthening of Java’s power grid, which will also support Indonesia’s low-carbon transition with 
the ability to integrate increased amounts of renewables into the grid. The program will finance a 
slice of the broader program in the RUPTL, 2021–2030 and enhance access to sustainable and 
reliable energy for the people in Western and Central Java.15 
 
8.  Overall development impacts. The program area is home to 112.0 million people, 
including 9.6 million poor and another 21.0 million near the poverty line, and hosts 11.3 million 
(56.3%) of Indonesia’s MSEs who employ 24.4 million (58.9%) of the country’s MSE workforce.16 
Green energy investments supported by the program have estimated GDP output multipliers of 
1.1–1.5 compared to 0.5–0.6 for fossil fuel energy investments and improve job creation by a ratio 
of 3:1 compared to spending on fossil fuels.17 Through the delivery of affordable, sustainable, and 
reliable electricity, the program will support Java’s economic recovery and transform its poorer 
areas into growth engines through agro-industries, tourism, and MSEs. 
 
9.  COVID-19 impact. As of October 2021, COVID-19 had led to more than 140,000 deaths 
in Indonesia.18 It has also affected the livelihood of about 30 million people through reduced work

4 
hours, suspended employment, or job losses, with the unemployment rate soaring to 7.1% as of 
August 2020, its highest since August 2011.19 This program will support government efforts to 
mitigate COVID-19 impacts through expanded employment opportunities, including for women, 
that  will  come  with  more  reliable  electricity,  new  investments,  and  resumption  of  public 
infrastructure projects, including in renewable energy. These actions are expected to facilitate a 
green, inclusive, and resilient recovery. The program will address the risks from COVID-19 
through (i) noncontact, digital, or social distancing strategies during training and community 
outreach programs; and (ii) stringent health and safety protocols during infrastructure work. 
 
10.  Contribution to the State Electricity Corporation’s reforms. The program will support 
four of the five PLN reform areas (para. 5): (i) innovation through technology and infrastructure 
upgrades  to  make  services  more  efficient  and  reliable,  including  e-procurement  and  other 
digitalization efforts; (ii) financial management reforms; (iii) renewable generation expansion and 
the promotion of clean energy use through electric vehicles; and (iv) enhancing career pathways 
for female staff by prioritizing spaces in technical training programs. 
 
11.   Gender gaps in access, skills, jobs, and leadership in the sector. Women’s labor 
force participation has stagnated since 2020, reaching only 55% in 2020 as compared to 84% for 
men.20 This differential is acute in the more technical professions. In 2018, women represented 
only 12% of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics tertiary education graduates, and 
in the high-tech industry, only 14% of women employed held professional or technical positions 
compared to 31% of men.21 To address this gender gap, state-owned enterprises such as the 
PLN are increasing the workforce opportunities for female staff by prioritizing spaces in technical 
training  programs  to  enhance  their  career  pathways.  Further,  state-owned  enterprises  are 
recognizing the importance of engaging all users of their services (for the PLN, provision of 
energy) in project outreach activities, acknowledging that previous female participation rate of 
20% was insufficient to respond to the broader needs and concerns of communities. 
 
12.  Modality. The RBL modality is suitable as it will (i) provide incentives for governance and 
efficiency reforms within the PLN’s systems, (ii) reduce high transaction costs associated with 
scattered small investments, (iii) increase accountability for delivering and sustaining results, 
(iv) consolidate gains in the PLN’s institutional strengthening from previous RBL programs (para. 
14), (v) provide incentives for clean and renewable energy initiatives, and (vi) leverage financing 
and improve development partner coordination. 
 
13.  Lessons learned. ADB has provided three RBL programs to date in the energy sector in 
Indonesia (footnote 11) and has captured a number of lessons based on its experience. The 
proposed fourth RBL program applies a number of relevant lessons, notably (i) avoiding past 
bottlenecks by focusing on disbursement-linked indicators (DLIs) that are within the PLN’s own 
control; (ii) involving all PLN stakeholders, including local units, in DLI development; and (iii) 
strengthening capacity to ensure timely, accurate, and complete data reports. In addition, this 
program  benefited  from  previous  RBL  programs  in  expanding  support  to  institutional 
strengthening, which has increased with successive programs but targeted different geographical 
regions.  For  example,  the  second  RBL  program  (Electricity  Grid  Development  Program)

Pandemic. Manila. 
20 International Labour Organization. 2020. Share of youth not in employment, education, or training (%). ILOSTAT. 
Geneva (accessed 24 August 2020). 
21 University of Melbourne. 2020. Will Indonesia’s 4.0 Revolution Leave Women Behind? (accessed March 2021).

5 
addressed gaps in the asset and waste management system for the first time.22 The third RBL 
program (Electricity Grid Development Program Phase 2) addressed the same issue, with greater 
focus on actions within the PLN’s control, and for the first time included a DLI on procurement.23 
Learning from the experience, the program will (i) address asset and waste management gaps 
through actions within the PLN’s own control, (ii) build on the previous procurement-related DLIs 
with additional refinement (para. 37), and (iii) include a first-time DLI on improving financial 
management. Previous RBL programs also showed the importance of contextualizing each 
program component, given the diversity of Indonesia. The program will focus on issues pertinent 
to Java. 
 
14.  Value added by ADB. ADB was the first development partner in Indonesia to support 
energy programs through the RBL modality, which has enabled close collaboration both with the 
PLN and other key development partners. ADB’s support of multiple phases of the RBL programs 
(footnote 11) provides an opportunity to see progress made and assess the value addition of ADB 
support,  which  includes  (i)  gender  mainstreaming;24 (ii)  financial management reforms  and 
governance  support  with  actions  and  the  first-time  DLI  to  improve  financial  management; 
(iii) procurement audits and increased transparency, building on the gains from Electricity Grid 
Development Program Phase 2 (footnote 22); (iv) renewable and clean energy reform support, 
including a new solar rooftop business model, increased electric vehicle infrastructure and sales, 
control center upgrades to reflect increased integration of renewable energy, and capacity 
building in renewable energy integration and battery storage; (v) system automation, drawing from 
international expertise; (vi) environmental safeguards system improvement; and (vii) disaster risk 
and climate change assessment to support the PLN’s new climate change management unit in 
improving grid resiliency. 
 
15.  Development partner coordination. ADB’s RBL operations are well-coordinated with 
key development partners.25 Previous RBL programs are cofinanced with the World Bank and 
German  development  cooperation  through  KfW  (footnote  11).  The  Asian  Infrastructure 
Investment Bank is supporting the PLN’s program in East Java and Bali to achieve full coverage 
of development partner support for Java island.26 The Government of Australia will support 
safeguard and results monitoring capacity, building activities for efficient program implementation, 
through a subproject TA of ADB-administered Sustainable Infrastructure Assistance Program.27 
ADB is also collaborating with other development partners for potential cofinancing opportunities.

16.  Alignment with strategic framework. The program is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 
and contributes to six operational priorities.28 It is also aligned with ADB’s country partnership 
strategy for Indonesia, 2020–2024, which emphasizes economic recovery through sustainable 
and resilient energy infrastructure,29 and is included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 
2021–2023.30 The program contributes to achieving Sustainable Development Goal 7 (affordable, 
reliable, sustainable, and modern energy for all) and Sustainable Development Goal 13 (climate 
action). 
 
C.  Program Scope 
 
17.  The PLN and ADB have agreed on an RBL program size of $1,411.0 million, of which the 
ADB loan will finance $600.0 million. The difference between the broader government program 
and the RBL program is summarized in Table 1.

D.  Program Results 
 
18.  Impact and outcome. The RBL program’s impact will be enhanced quality of life in 
Indonesian society through the provision of reliable electricity (footnote 6). The outcome will be 
enhanced access to sustainable and reliable energy for the population in Western and Central 
Java, with four outcome DLIs to measure program results. 31 Reliability will be measured by the 
System Average Interruption Frequency Index (DLI 1) and the reduction in the average duration 
of recovery per medium-voltage feeder line interruption (DLI 2). Clean energy use  will be 
measured  by  PLN  energy  sales  at  electricity  supply  and  electric  vehicle  charging  stations 
 
28 The six operational priorities are (i) poverty and inequality reduction (1.2, 1.3); (ii) gender equality and women’s 
empowerment (2.1); (iii) climate change, climate and disaster resilience, and environmental sustainability (3.1, 3.3); 
(iv) more livable cities (4.1); (v) rural development and food security (5.1); and (vi) strengthened governance and 
institutional capacity (6.1, 6.2). ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and 
Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
29 The areas of alignment are accelerating economic recovery through energy infrastructure; strengthening resilience 
through climate change mitigation and environmental sustainability; and promoting governance, institutions, and 
capacity. ADB. 2020. Country Partnership Strategy: Indonesia, 2020–2024—Emerging Stronger. Manila. 
30 A change in loan size was made from the original $400 million to $600 million at the request of the PLN because of 
increase in geographic coverage of the program from Central Java to include Western Java. ADB. 2020. Country 
Operations Business Plan: Indonesia, 2021–2023. Manila.

(DLI 3).32 The PLN’s efforts to strengthen financial sustainability will be measured by the earnings 
before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization as a percentage of revenue margin (DLI 4). 
An indicator not linked to disbursement will track transmission and distribution losses.33 The 
following three output results will contribute to the outcome. 
 
19.  Output 1: Power grid rehabilitated, strengthened, and expanded. Progress toward 
this output will be tracked by DLIs that monitor (i) the reconductoring (replacing the current 
carrying conductors) of transmission lines and the rehabilitation and/or extension of medium-
voltage distribution lines (DLI 5); and (ii) the enhancement of power grid automation and other 
upgrades (DLI 6). DLI 6 will support the upgrading of the Java–Bali load dispatch center to a 
modern central transmission control center and the installation of remotely controlled distribution 
switchgear. The program will also support a geographic information system-based integrated 
distribution management system for assets, customer services, and operation and maintenance, 
and the expansion of an advanced electrical metering system. 
 
20.  Output 2: Clean energy use promoted. Output 2 will support the development of a new 
business model to expand PLN-owned solar photovoltaic systems on rooftop space connected to 
the PLN grid (DLI 7). An indicator not linked to disbursement will track the expansion of electricity 
supply and electric vehicle charging stations. Output 2 will also support training for PLN staff 
nationwide, including female professionals, on emerging technologies, such as grid automation, 
electric vehicle charging, and energy storage (DLI 8), with partial support from a TA grant (para. 
28). 
 
21.  Output 3: Institutional capacity strengthened. This output will (i) improve asset and 
waste management through rehabilitating warehouses and constructing new hazardous waste 
storage  facilities  to  meet  improved  health,  safety,  and  environmental  criteria  (DLI  9); 
(ii) strengthen the PLN’s procurement system by expanding and monitoring the e-procurement 
and  systems,  applications,  and  products  in  data  processing  (enterprise  resource  planning 
software integrated system) (DLI 10); and (iii) support the PLN to conduct consumer education 
on safe and productive energy use through more inclusive outreach with at least 30% female 
participation (DLI 11). 
 
22.  Development and verification of indicators. The DLI targets and results chain were 
developed in a year-long consultative process with experienced system planners in the PLN, 
based on (i) the PLN’s actual performance over the past period, (ii) RUPTL targets, (iii) the 
difference that the RBL program’s financing would bring to infrastructure upgrades and electricity 
reliability, and (iv) the impacts of COVID-19.34 The process ensured that the DLIs and other 
performance indicators would provide ambitious yet achievable measures of progress toward the 
outputs and outcome, and that outputs were sufficient to achieve the outcome. All DLIs will be 
verified by an independent verification agent (IVA). Table 2 summarizes the DLIs and the share 
of ADB financing allocated to each. Following ADB’s RBL modality, the allocation was based on 
the relative importance of each DLI for the program outcome.

24.  Program financing. The PLN has requested a regular loan of $600 million from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources to help finance the program. The loan will have a 20-year term, 
including a grace period of 5 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s 
London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a commitment charge of 0.15% per 
year; and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. Based on the 
straight-line method, the average maturity is 12.75 years, and there is no maturity premium 
payable to ADB. The ADB loan proceeds are not linked to any specific expenditure item but are 
an integral part of the program’s overall financing plan. The financing plan for the broader PLN 
program and the RBL program is shown in Table 4.

F.  Capacity Development and Program Action Plan 
 
26.  The program action plan (PAP) will address the needs identified during assessments and 
strengthen the PLN’s capacity for achieving program results sustainably.36 The PAP includes 
actions in specific technical areas, monitoring and evaluation (M&E), fiduciary management, 
gender, and safeguards to complement the program’s physical investments. 
 
G.  Technical Assistance 
 
27.  The TA will help strengthen the capacity of PLN staff nationwide (of which 23% will be 
women) in emerging technologies. The TA will support training on (i) power grid system planning 
and automation; and (ii) solar photovoltaic integration to grids, electric vehicle charging services, 
and utility-scale energy storage systems.37 The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which 
$500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. The PLN will provide support with counterpart staff, 
office and workshop space, office supplies, secretarial assistance, local communication facilities, 
and other in-kind contributions. 
 
H.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
28.  The PLN is the executing agency. The implementation of the program will be undertaken 
by the PLN’s regional offices and units, with oversight by PLN headquarters in Jakarta.38 A 
program management team established at the PLN, with the team lead nominated by the PLN, 
will monitor and report on progress. An IVA will be engaged to conduct verification of program 
results and PAP implementation.39 The program will be implemented from January 2021 to 
December 2025.40 
 
III.  SUMMARY OF ASSESSMENTS 
 
A.  Program Technical Assessments 
 
29.  Program soundness and results assessment. The technical assessment indicates a 
robust program design and sound implementation arrangements with no major technical issues 
or concerns that will affect the DLIs.41 The results framework was considered, the DLIs are critical

indicators  for  achieving  RBL  program results, the  M&E  system  is fit for  purpose,  and the 
expenditure framework and financing plan are robust. The program will enhance the reliability of 
electricity  supply,  especially  in  areas  prone  to  lower  power  quality  and  interruptions.  The 
program’s support for a centralized control center and advanced automation systems would 
further improve transmission grid stability, while improving distribution automation systems would 
reduce the frequency and duration of outages. Specific mitigation measures to minimize technical 
issues will be addressed through the PAP. 
 
30.  Central Java is among the top three provinces with the highest potential for rooftop solar 
on residential buildings.42 The program supports the development of a new business model to 
increase rooftop solar photovoltaic uptake as a low-carbon solution that is technically simple and 
cost-effective. The program also supports the continued rollout of the PLN’s electric charging and 
electric vehicle infrastructure. In summary, the PLN's plan to develop the power systems in 
Western and Central Java is strongly justified and operationally  viable and is expected to 
(i) improve service quality and reliability, (ii) expand access to electricity for households and 
businesses in line with growing demand, (iii) promote renewable energy use, and (iv) promote 
clean energy use for transport. 
 
31.  Poverty reduction. The program is expected to expand livelihood options, reduce income 
poverty, reduce time poverty, and promote the expansion of MSEs (paras. 8 and 9). About 9.1 
million poor households, including 1.8 million poor households headed by women, will benefit 
from having access to reliable electricity and expanded livelihood opportunities. 
 
32.  Gender. The program is categorized as effective gender mainstreaming. The program 
proposes to bring time savings to women and girls, who carry the burden of household drudgery 
and responsibilities, while improving their potential to engage in productive energy-reliant income-
generating activities. In the program provinces, women’s median earnings range from 29.9% 
(West Java) to 40.9% (Yogyakarta Special Region) of the median male earnings.43 In 2016, small 
and  medium-sized  enterprises  headed  by  women  contributed  9.1%  of  GDP.44 Formalizing 
electrical  connections  in  urban  poor  areas  will  make  households  headed  by  women  less 
vulnerable to exploitation. Improved access to electricity will improve household health outcomes 
by minimizing air pollution and fire risks and stimulate increased participation of MSEs owned by 
women, thereby contributing to addressing the gender gap in income poverty.45 This program will 
also address the non-income dimensions of poverty, such as time poverty, irregular water supply, 
and suboptimal public health facilities, by providing a reliable electricity supply. In addition, the 
program  is  supporting female  professionals  in the  PLN  to  increase  and  demonstrate their 
knowledge and application of new technologies through prioritizing 23% of training opportunities 
for female staff (DLI 8).46 This will improve women’s job skills, incomes, and career options, and 
support men and women to improve livelihood opportunities by building their knowledge and 
understanding of safe and productive energy use (with a minimum participation rate of 30% for

B.  Program Systems Assessments 
 
33.  Monitoring and evaluation systems. The M&E systems assessment conducted for this 
RBL built on earlier assessments. The PLN’s M&E system has the capacity to track all DLIs and 
other indicators and report regularly on these and involve stakeholders in the process. The PLN’s 
management reporting information system already monitors some DLIs.48 
 
34.  Fiduciary systems. The program will use the PLN’s fiduciary systems for financial 
management, procurement, and audit. An assessment of the systems to determine their ability to 
manage fiduciary risks showed that they provide reasonable assurance that the RBL program 
funds will be used as intended, with due consideration for economy and efficiency. 
 
35.  Financial management. A financial management assessment was concluded in 2021, 
with  reference  to  ADB  guidance  on  financial  management.  The  previous  RBL  financial 
management risk assessments conducted in 2015, 2018, and 2020 assessed the PLN’s overall 
financial  management  risk  moderate.  The  financial  management  assessment  for  the  RBL 
program indicates that the moderate rating is still valid. The main deficiencies and risks in the 
PLN’s financial management systems will be addressed through activities under the PAP. 
 
36.  Procurement  system.  A  procurement  assessment  conducted  during  2020–2021 
confirmed PLN’s procurement practices to be aligned with previous findings, and the overall 
procurement framework is considered appropriate for program implementation. The RBL program 
will rely on the PLN’s systems and will exclude high-value contracts in accordance with ADB’s 
RBL policy. PLN regional offices and units (PLN transmission offices and PLN distribution offices) 
issue purchase orders under a framework contract established by PLN headquarters and conduct 
the procurement of works and installation services. A key lesson from the ongoing RBL programs 
is the low level of utilization of the procurement and contract monitoring application, despite its 
wide availability. The program addresses these through DLI 10. For the RBL program, the PLN 
has agreed to undertake internal procurement audits of 10% of all contracts each year.  
 
37.  Integrity  due  diligence  was  conducted  on  the  PLN,  the  members  of  its  board  of 
commissioners, and its board of directors, and no significant or potentially significant integrity risks 
were detected.49 Guidelines to prevent or mitigate fraud, corruption, and other prohibited activities 
in results-based lending for programs were explained to and discussed with the government and 
the PLN.50 
 
38.  Safeguard systems. The program safeguard systems currently in place at the PLN are 
broadly aligned with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). The PLN has established a 
comprehensive system of guidelines and decrees that supplements the national regulatory 
framework  for  environmental  and  social  safeguards.  The  program  safeguard  systems 
assessment drew on previous assessments for prior RBL programs (footnote 11); field visits; and 
consultations with various PLN offices, government and nongovernment institutions in Jakarta, 
Banten, West Java, and Central Java, and a number of affected people and indigenous peoples

39.  Environment safeguards. The program is categorized B for environmental safeguards, 
as eligible activities are anticipated to have minor, site-specific, and reversible impacts during 
construction.  Activities  that  would  be  classified  category  A  for  environment  as  per  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), or those specified in the 2019 regulation issued by the 
Ministry of Environment and Forestry (MOEF), are not eligible under the RBL program and will be 
excluded during the screening of annual work plans.53 The PLN will develop standard operating 
procedures on management of waste and materials, with targets that follow MOEF regulations 
and guidelines.54 
 
40.  Climate change assessment. The program climate risk is assessed medium.55 ADB will 
support the PLN to assess the vulnerability of the PLN’s existing and planned power grid network 
to climate and geophysical hazards in Western and Central Java. Climate mitigation is estimated 
to cost $94.5 million and climate adaptation is estimated to cost $29.3 million. ADB will finance 
100% of mitigation and adaptation costs. 
 
41.  Social safeguards. The program safeguard systems assessment identified gaps in the 
PLN’s institutional capacity and conduct of social safeguards systems,56 which will be addressed 
through the PAP. The safeguards category of this program is B for both involuntary resettlement 
and indigenous peoples. For involuntary resettlement, land required for program activities is 
expected to be minimal with no physical displacement. There will be no relocation of indigenous 
peoples, and the impacts on indigenous peoples communities are minimal, if encountered at all.57 
Screening for both involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples will be conducted rigorously 
to exclude category A activities. The safeguard program actions include measures to strengthen 
meaningful consultations, grievance redress mechanisms, the screening process, record-keeping 
of negotiated land settlement, monitoring, and programs for indigenous peoples on enhancing 
access to and awareness of electricity.

44.  I am satisfied that the proposed results-based loan would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
loan  of  $600,000,000  to  Perusahaan  Listrik  Negara  (State  Electricity  Corporation)  to  be

Program—Western and Central Java, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, 
with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB's London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility; for a term of 20 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such other 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and 
guarantee agreements presented to the Board.

Key Program Actions 
1. Program scope, by 2021: 
1.1 Establish criteria for prioritizing transmission and distribution interventions in the program and plan 
      and finalize the 5-year transmission reconductoring and distribution line extension plan. 
1.2 Prepare distribution automation plan for 5 years. 
1.3 Develop a business plan for new SPKLU-POSOs. 
2. Technical system and impact monitoring 
2.1 Establish information sources, measuring systems, and procedure for calculating and reporting 
SAIFI and SAIDI (by 2021). 
2.2 Prepare solar photovoltaic rollout plan, year by year (annually, from 2022). 
2.3 Monitor the development of geographic information system-based distribution management system 
(annually, from 2022). 
2.4 Develop and publish technical guidelines on (i) electric vehicle charging; (ii) rooftop solar 
photovoltaic; and (iii) distribution management system, including operational manuals (by 2022). 
2.5 Monitor the additional number of PLN customers in Western and Central Java subregions, with 
separate reporting by residential, business, commercial, and social (annually, from 2021). 
3. Monitoring and evaluation 
3.1 Establish quarterly reviews on DLI progress and RBL program implementation (annually, from 
2021). 
4. Gender from 2021 on: 
4.1 Mainstream gender through capacity building and customer education in the implementation of DLI 
8 and DLI 11. 
4.2 Conduct training of trainers in new technologies, including women trainers. 
4.3 Establish sex-disaggregated database to monitor workshops and trainings. 
4.4 Measure and/or validate knowledge acquired from workshops and trainings. 
4.5 Appoint gender focal persons for program action plan and DLI implementation. 
5. Financial management 
5.1 Prepare and submit a report on PLN’s time bound short-term liquidity management initiatives 
(annually from 2021). 
5.2 Reconcile the updated annual forecast submitted by PLN against actuals on an annual basis and 
provide a variance report to ADB. 
6. Procurement 
6.1 Prepare and submit accurate quarterly procurement monitoring reports, based on data in the 
integrated e-procurement and SAP systems (annual report for 2021; quarterly reports from 2022).  
6.2 Allow competitive bidding with international participation for procurement involving new 
technologies and/or expertise not yet established in the national market (from 2021).  
6.3 Conduct internal procurement audits each year on 10% of all contracts at UIDs and UITs, with each 
audit covering the previous year’s procurement transactions (annually from 2022). 
7. Safeguards: Environment 
7.1 Strengthen institutional capacity on environmental safeguards (from 2021). 
7.2 Strengthen environmental safeguards screening, in accordance with the program safeguard 
systems assessmentg (from 2021). 
7.3 Ensure environmental compliance with national regulatory requirements (from 2021).

18  Appendix 1 
7.4 Prepare consolidated annual report on implementation of environmental safeguard program actions 
by UID/UIT (annually from Q1 2022). 
8. Safeguards: Social 
8.1 Strengthen institutional capacity on social safeguards through actions detailed in program 
safeguard systems assessmentg (from 2021). 
8.2 Strengthen social safeguards screening (from 2021).

metadata.Keywords: indonesia, perusahaan listrik negara, java island, clean energy, access to energy, electricity transmission, energy infrastructure, power grid, 53220-001, loan 4164, ta 6874, adb projects, project approval, terms and conditions, rrp, approved projects
metadata.Subject:
The program covers five provinces in the western and central parts of Java island— Banten, Central Java, Jakarta Special Capital Region, West Java, and Yogyakarta Special Region—collectively home to 41% of Indonesia’s 270 million people. The expected outcome is enhanced access to sustainable and reliable energy for the population in Western and Central Java. Three output results contribute to the outcome: (i) power grid rehabilitated, strengthened, and expanded; (ii) clean energy use promoted; and (iii) institutional capacity strengthened.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated November 2021 is provided for the ADB project 53220-001 in Indonesia.
metadata.Title: Sustainable and Reliable Energy Access Program: Report and Recommendation of the President
